results.title: Clint Eastwood: out of the shadows
results.creator_credit: Bruce Ricker, BBC-TV, American Masters and Rhapsody Films
results.brief_description: This documentary on American actor and director Clint Eastwood traces his long career from his early appearances in B-grade films like ‘Tarantula’ (1955) and ‘Return of the Creature’ (1955) and his seven years spent playing the character of Rowdy on the long running television series ‘Rawhide’, to his iconic performances in Leone’s spaghetti westerns and the ‘Dirty Harry’ series. Extensive clips from the films he acted in and directed, are combined with interviews with Eastwood and his contemporaries including Martin Scorsese, James Garner, Janet Maslin, Sergio Leone, Curtis Hanson, William Goldman, Donald Sutherland and Meryl Streep. Influences on Eastwood’s life and career such as his enduring interest in jazz music are also explored. Narrated by Morgan Freeman.

results.title: Cliff hangers
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Over a gleaming icefiled and up steep cliffs of bare rock, the camera follows members of the Alpine Club of Canada. Before they set out we are introduced to the climbers’ basic equipment and learn the uses of rope and ice axe. Excitement mounts as the Alpinists leap gaping chasms and drag themselves up sheer walls of rock. At the top, they pause for a view over the sea of mountains surrounding their own vanquished peak. Narrated by Lorne Greene.

results.title: Climbers (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Rosalind Gillespie, Australian Film Commission and Silver Films
results.brief_description: A visually dramatic film which can be used to promote discussion and interest in the art of dance, dance interpretation, choreography and communication. ‘Climbers’ presents an allegory in contemporary dance of the international struggle for women’s liberation, the theme being drawn from the Japanese Women’s ascent of Mount Everest in 1975. An excellent example of contemporary dance in Australia in the 1980’s - Margaret Barr was a significant figure (as a choreographer) of this period and earlier. Film direction by Rosalind Gillespie shows original approach.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rosalind Gillespie, Australian Film Commission and Silver Films

results.title: Climb for the top
results.brief_description: Shows a team of mountain climbers preparing for and actually climbing Mt McKinley, the highest point in North America. Members discuss the elements of teamwork that are necessary to make it to the top. Narration by Sandy Fidell, Jeannie Rose, Don Lauria.
results.description: Shows a team of mountain climbers preparing for and actually climbing Mt McKinley, the highest point in North America. Members discuss the elements of teamwork that are necessary to make it to the top. Narration by Sandy Fidell, Jeannie Rose, Don Lauria.

results.title: Click go the shears
results.creator_credit: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow and Link Films
results.brief_description: A highly stylised humorous treatment of the famous Australian ballad, using a minimum of animation. Sung by Cedric McLaughlin and the Link Singers.

results.title: Climats = Climates of Love
results.brief_description:
Philippe and Odile divorce after a stormy marriage. But Philippe’s new relationship with Isabelle proves equally disastrous. Having gone from whimsical Odile to calm and composed Isabelle, Philippe is hopelessely bored and starts looking for a diversion with Misa. Just when happiness and desire seem to come his way, Isabelle and Odile send cries for help.

Credits: Producer, Robert Vignon ; director, Stellio Lorenzi ;
writers, Stellio Lorenzi, Rene Cortade, Rodolphe-Maurice Arlaud, Alain
Decaux.
Cast: Marina Vlady, Jean-Pierre Marielle, Michel Piccoli, Emmanuelle Riva, Alexandra Stewart.

results.title: Clementine Tango
results.brief_description:
Charles, a law student, shares a sumptuous Paris apartment with his sister. One day, he finds a very strange love letter in the pocket of his father’s tuxedo. While trying to understand his father’s love entanglements, he is led to a Pigalle nightclub where act after act is performed with the intent of splintering bourgeois sexual mores into humorous pieces. The ‘cinema du look’ is not quite confined to the films of Beineix, Besson and Carax, the tree neo-baroque ‘wonder boys’. Caroline Roboh’s camp cabaret ‘Clementine Tango’ (1982) belongs to the genre too, as does Virginie Thevenet ‘La nuit porte-jaretelles’ (1985), which led ‘Les Cahiers du Cinema’ to coin the phrase ‘style Forum des Halles’, and prompted an attack from ‘Positif’ on the quality of the narrative, acting, and portrayal of sexuality.” Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Vladimir Forgency ; director, Caroline Roboh ; writer, Caroline Roboh ; photography, Mario Barroso.
Cast: Claire Pascal, Francois Helvey, Caroline Roboh, Arturo Brachetti, Josephine Larsen.
